title: Re: O WHYYYYYYYYYYY?
content:
Hello everyone.

I haven't checked these forums for several years now, so I was kinda surprised when I saw Isis II still being discussed at all.

I programmed Worminator and the more recent Worminator 3, and was the original Isis II programmer. I still tinker with Worminator on and off, and the game has undergone many improvements over the years.

If you are interested, I can provide you with code from one of the more recent builds, though it is largely the same structurally. Honestly though, I'd do things totally different if I were making another sidescroller today, so don't be fooled into thinking that Isis II or Worminator is a really good example of how to code a sidescroller. None the less, it should be easy to understand at least the basic flow of the game.

title: Mindtrip.
content:
Wow, greetings! Good to have you here! Of course Isis II is still being talked about... besides Z-1's engine, it's the best fan game yet to be created. I'd definitely be interested to see some more recent code.

It would also be helpful if you could point out some books, websites or other resources you use to learn the artform in the first place. In particular, things like sprite management and general code and data structure.

Woah... I can't believe Terminator 3 was released almost four years ago! I haven't watched it since it was at the cinema. Actually... it was barely a month before I discovered this forum! How very intriguing. This thread just keeps dredging up memories.

You might find [url=http://fortvortabella.commanderkeen.org/forum/index.php]The Barricades[/url] interesting, if you plan to partake in the community more permanently. It's a quiet place at the moment, but there's one way to change that...

title: Re: Mindtrip.
content:
Hmm well honestly, I didn't really find any useful articles or books about game programming when I started fooling around with this stuff. I had some experience making simple games with QBasic in the past, but that was about it.

Worminator actually started off as just a tile map editor, I was originally going to make it edit keen 1-3 levels. Then I just fooled around with making a little stick man walk around the levels instead (no slopes, no other sprites, no animations at this point). It turned out to be pretty easy, just had to check a few tiles every time you moved to see if they were solid or not.

After that I just slowly hacked more and more into the game over the next year or so. I just learned everything by trial and error (even though the game contains a good many errors still!).

The basic approach is really simple. You have 4 tile grids, a background graphics layer, a foreground graphics layer, an info tile layer, and a graphic properties layer. Background/foreground layers just have pointers to graphical tiles, the info layer contains info about what the tile is (a slope, a wall, a breakable tile, empty space, etc...) and the graphical properties layer is used for special masking effects (like making the foreground translucent).

For sprites, I just made a fixed size array of sprite structures, which look something like this:

typedef struct SPRITE {
&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp int sprite_active;
&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp int sprite_type;
&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp char in_range;
&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp int timer;
&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp char animation_state;
&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp int width, height;
&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp int action_state;
&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp int frame;
&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp float hit_points_left;
&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp float x_position_in_pixels, y_position_in_pixels;
&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp float x_acceleration, y_acceleration;
&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp char direction;
&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp unsigned char rotate_factor;
&nbsp &nbsp &nbsp &nbsp } SPRITE;

Then I made a bunch of functions to spawn sprites, move sprites, etc... Each of these functions would take an index number that references a sprite in the array. There were also separate AI functions for every type of sprite. Then every frame I just loop through the sprite array and call the appropriate AI routine for every sprite, and pass it its index within the array.

Its all really basic honestly. I'll zip up the latest worminator code for you later if you like. You need MSVC 6.0+ and winallegro to run it though.

content:

title: Slice Dice Thrice
content:
[hr]DML For sprites, I just made a fixed size array of sprite structures
[hr]I'm determined to establish a linked list sprite system. It just seems so untidy working with straight arrays. I've been adopting some C++ features throughout the course of this year, so there's been much experimentation with vectors and lists. They make things a bit simpler, but I don't think I like their abstractness so much.

All this backflipping in my approach is probably the main hurdle I face, moreso than any lack of understanding. Hearing other people describe how they structure things helps a lot though.

[hr]DML I'll zip up the latest worminator code for you later if you like.
[hr]That'd be great. I look forward to it.

[hr]DaVince (Once I know how to install Allegro on my MinGW compiler... The instructions delivered with Allegro don't work at all.)
[hr]What problems are you having? I've been able to setup Allegro with MinGW many times in the past following the provided instructions, so I may be of some help.

Though I don't think I've updated MinGW in a year or so (the website confuses me now), so things may have changed in some ways.

You might want to investigate Dev-C++ if you've not already. It can be setup to run straight out of the box (including MinGW). Allegro, along with its examples and various associated libraries, can be downloaded and installed via the package system.

However, I would suggest setting MinGW up manually first--that way you have a better understanding of how it fits together. Although I find all that low-level work can be habit-forming. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-stoned.gif[/img]

title: Allegro Presto
content:
I'll uh, make a new topic about this to avoid clutter, ok?

EDIT: no, nevermind. As I was writing my help needed topic and walking through the steps again, I noticed I forgot to unpack the minimal DX package to my compiler directory. After I did that, no problems appeared again (I was able to run fix.bat where I couldn't before). Sigh.

EDIT 2: okay, compilation error. Hooray.

[pre] I posted lots of errors here. Problem fixed, ignore.[/pre]

[quote]Quote:[hr]Commander Spleen - You might want to investigate Dev-C++ if you've not already. It can be setup to run straight out of the box (including MinGW). Allegro, along with its examples and various associated libraries, can be downloaded and installed via the package system.[hr][/quote]
Already done that - I like Code::Blocks better. Better interface, extendable, open-source, cross-platform, has workspaces where Dev-C++ has not. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img]
Not sure if that can include libs automatically, but I do know it doesn't support devpacks (yet). Or maybe it requires a script (extension) to support devpacks.

EDIT: okay, C::B DOES support Devpacks, there's a plugin for it, but it doesn't support drag and drop installing of the packs. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-cheeky.gif[/img] ____________
Don't think of me as an ordinary man.

Even though I am an ordinary man.

title: Thanks!
content:
Wow, Thanks DML!

I had forgotten just how far we really got! Seeing those screenshots of Keen in the green jungle level really brought back memories... pity we never got it finished.

Do you recall exactly what we DIDN'T do / still had to finish off, apart from the actual Level design & In-between sequences, from my memory, most stuff worked fine (items, keys, etc). Oh, the enemies weren't complete were they...

title: wow
content:
Holy crap, it's been a while since someone who hasn't posted since before I came on here came back. (Been here since 2001, under various accounts)

Welcome back, Geoff.

title: Re: wow
content:
Well, I left the project well before it was canceled. I believe I did everything code wise up to the first demo, but past that others took over.

There really was a lot done and working. I think the biggest issue with the game was that it kept ballooning out of control. Every time I finished a feature, I got requests for 5 more. I just didn't have the time to work on the game that much anymore so I had to bail. If you remember, the original idea I had for the game was basically a worminator clone with Keen graphics, so I never planned on having it grow so much.

I think there were at least 3-4 full tilesets done, most if not all of the weapons, and a good number of enemies. The biggest problem was just content, getting all the levels done, finishing the art, etc...

title: Re: wow
content:
Oh, incidentally, any pixel artists here willing to do a little work for Worminator 3.1? I need a few cartoon portraits drawn and a few other small things. If anyone can help out, please let me know.

I can't pay you of course, but you will get full credit for any work and alpha versions of the game to play with. Everything that I need done shouldn't take a competent artist more than a few hours to complete I don't think.

title: Hmm
content: It's good to get in touch with everyone again but a lot has changed in all these years - I think resurrection might be taking it a bit too far!  Personally, I don't really have the time or passion to do anything Keenish anymore, but that's not to say I don't enjoy seeing the new projects and hopefully one day I'l get my act together and download Dosbox and try to play all this stuff coming out!

I don't have the time or desire to work on the game again either.

However, I am wrapping up worminator 3.1, and I am thinking about including a little homage to Isis II hidden in one of the levels if no one involved with the game minds.

I want to have a hidden secret portal in one of the new levels that teleports you to another dimension, which will be a short little segment of Isis II art with 1-2 enemies mabye. Would this bother anyone? I was planning on using the outdoor forest tileset for this. I have a secret little alternate ending planned too if this goes through.

title: re: Forge
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]How bout Forge315, is he still hanging around the board maybe by some other nickname? Used to be on the newsletter team. [hr][/quote]

If I remember correctly, he switched to JosephBurke for a while, and then departed from the community sometime in 2002 or 2003. It's a shame, because he was really looking forward to the potential of Keen4-6 modding... which became a reality less than a year after he left.

Man, seeing that Oueff stuff brings back memories. I was only on that style board for maybe a month, before the switch.

title: Re: re: Forge
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]And while we're reminiscing, I just couldn't resist:
web.archive.org/web/*/htt...cgi/mb5517

Ah, the good old days. Now I have to solve the mystery as to why, even though I've been posting for 10 years, I only show up in 2000... [hr][/quote]
Wow Flaose that's a real awesome way to look back. Am I crazy if I know half of these Keeners even when I was not around back then?

Some gems:

[quote]Quote:[hr]I believe that you are trying deliberatly to look like an extremely stupid person too see what stupid messages I'll post, then show them to your friends and laugh your head off all night. Really, what kind of person wouldn't even think to learn from their mistakes? Of course you're pretending! Just like your various alianses, just like your "various ages"... And now you're probably laughing your head off saying "NOW he realises! What an idiot!... Hay, Joe, you want som' ore beer, dude? Hay, can 'ou believe this guy?! Even his last post which was supposed to shock me or som'ing looked like something posted by an idiot Keen-admirer nerd that he is." So how old are you really, Peter? Neil? Brian? Gee, what am I thinking; do you have any friends? Is what I said close to the truth? Looks like it, either that or it comes close; noone can be as much of an idiot as you pretend to be. I guess unless the person was mentally ill, of course... (n/t) (Snortimer)[hr][/quote]

[quote]Quote:[hr]I don't think Jesus Christ ever talked about that forum. (n/t) (Cho'gall)[hr][/quote] -----------------
